newsitem.title: HONG KONG: FEATURE - I shall return, says Hong Kong democrat.
newsitem.headline: FEATURE - I shall return, says Hong Kong democrat.

text.p: Feisty Hong Kong legislator Christine Loh represents a tough-minded new breed of democrat in Hong Kong -- but in just over six weeks she faces an uncertain period in the political wilderness.
Loh, among Hong Kong's first generation of Western-educated Asian democracy activists, vows to regain an influential voice after China takes over the British colony.
Determined to battle on for civil liberties, Loh, 41, is undeterred by Hong Kong's shadowy future as a Special Administrative Region under the overall control of Beijing.
"We want to build a political culture in Hong Kong -- competitive but not adversial," she says of life under the Chinese communist flag.
She will be swept out of political office, one of 33 lawmakers to lose their jobs when the British hand over their colony to China at midnight on June 30.

Angered by mild democratic reforms introduced as more than 150 years of British colonial rule drew to a close, China will dismantle the Legislative Council and replace it with a selected interim chamber, expected to serve for about a year.
Loh, who has spared neither Britain nor China during her political career, refused to cooperate with Beijing's selection process.
Along with little more than half the members of the 60-seat existing chamber, she faces a post-handover future out in the cold -- at first anyway.
The opponent she defeated in elections in 1995 accepted a seat. If it rankles, Loh does not let it show.
Instead, she has focused her energies on founding a new political party, the Citizens' Party, and is looking ahead to contesting elections expected in 1998.
She is an ardent advocate of democracy, of universal adult suffrage and environmental responsibility.
"For those of us who are relatively young, to be able to say we've gone through the process of getting the people's mandate, it's a big deal," she said in a recent interview.
"It might not be a big deal in the West, but for us it's a big deal," she said.
China has promised Hong Kong people they will run Hong Kong and pledged to permit full democracy within 10 years -- although the details remain hazy.
A single woman, Loh, with her crisp British accent and mastery of Chinese dialects, is a representative of the first generation of Hong Kong people to feel they truly belong to Hong Kong.
Most are the sons and daughters of refugees who fled turmoil in China and landed in the colony, a tiny corner of stability on the mainland's southern flank.
Few share their parents' view that the territory is merely a waiting room en route to the West or, one day, back to China.
They want to run their own lives in Hong Kong.

Loh, educated both in Hong Kong and in Britain where she earned a law degree, spent her early career working as a commodities trader for Philipp Brothers and Phibro in Hong Kong and China and for a trader CIM Co Ltd in Hong Kong.

She opened Philipp's representative office in Beijing in 1980, one of the first wave of U.S. companies to establish a toehold in China when the once reclusive country began opening its doors to the West.
Loh became a full time legislator in 1994, but cut her teeth in politics a decade earlier.
She chaired the Hong Kong Observers -- a grouping of mostly young, professional Hong Kong people who pushed for more open and representative government.
This alarmed some members of the colonial establishment and the older generation disturbed at seeing people in their thirties rocking the boat.
A generation clash is not surprising, Loh said, but she insists she has no time for the concept of "Asian values" as espoused by elderly leaders such as Singapore leader Lee Kuan Yew.
"We are the fulfilment of our parents' dreams. They wanted us to be able to compete with the West -- that's why they educated us in the Western manner," she said.
"We're comfortable with Western ways, but it doesn't make us any less Asian."

"I believe that Asians have a distinctive culture and history but I get very upset when Asian governments use bits of history and culture to say Asian values mean Asians naturally accept authoritarianism. It's a distorted argument."
